subject: Hannah Storm: The Imus Story Keeps Getting Bigger
body:

  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday Morning | Face The Nation 






April 11, 
      2007
 
Hi, 
      everybody,
 
We've 
      made it halfway through the week and there was so much to talk about this 
      morning. It seems like the Don Imus story gets bigger by the day. 
      
 
As most of you 
      know, after Rutgers
University lost the NCAA 
      women's basketball championship game to Tennessee, the radio talk 
      show host the next day used racist and sexist language to describe the 
      team. We spoke with Rutgers 
      head coach C. Vivian Stringer and team captain Essence Carson 
      about how hurtful those remarks have been at a time that should have been 
      a celebration of their athletic ability. The team is emotionally exhausted 
      and disheartened.
 
Coach Stringer is 
      one of the legendary coaches in women's basketball, whom I first met 
      over 20 years ago. She is a model of strength, having endured, among other 
      things, her baby daughter suffering from meningitis and the death of her 
      husband. Coach Stringer has always been a champion of doing what's right, 
      by being the first black cheerleader at her high school, and her players 
      are taking the high road by meeting with Imus to hear what he has to say. 
      Remarkably, so far, no one at Rutgers has called for his 
      firing. 
 
Meanwhile, we asked CBS News correspondents Jeff Greenfield and Bob Schieffer whether or not they would 
      continue to be on Imus' program, and they both said, "yes." However, 
      several sponsors have suspended ads on the program and high-profile 
      guests, like Cal Ripken Jr., have cancelled appearances on the show. 
      
 
Sports 
      was in the news again today, as an announcement was scheduled about the 
      sexual assault charges against former Duke Lacrosse 
      players. Katie Couric will anchor the CBS Evening News from 
      Raleigh, 
      N.C., tonight, and 
      Harry will anchor The Early Show from 
      Raleigh tomorrow morning, 
      providing comprehensive coverage of the breaking developments in the 
      Duke
University rape case. You can 
      also check CBSNews.com 
      for the latest.
 
Also tomorrow, we 
      will bring you the highlights from Dave's All-Access Adventures, and 
      our friend Tori Ritchie will show us how to make crepes.
 
Take 
      care,

Hannah 
      StormEarlyShow@cbs.com
